lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify key details about San San’s journey by choosing correct answers (e.g., numbering actions in order).
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play short video clips. Ask: “What’s San San doing?” Students number the actions in order based on what they hear and see.
stretchStrategies: Turn the video review into a “Freeze and Speak” game. Play the video and freeze it at any scene. Students describe what’s happening.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say how their lives are similar to or different from the characters in the video.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Ask: “How is San San’s life different from yours?” Use a Venn diagram on the board to compare.
stretchStrategies: Turn the video review into a “Freeze and Speak” game. Play the video and freeze it at any scene. Students describe what’s happening.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can discuss how to help others and show empathy when working together.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Empathy) Ask: “How can we help people?” Students work in small groups to draw or list simple ways to help others (e.g., “Help carry books”).

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.

Systematic kinds of silent letters, such as 'magic e' in late or mote, or silent gh in thought and bought, are entirely alien to Vietnamese. They are often acquired as sight words first; the teacher can explain at higher levels.

Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
